author: A_Brickset_user
title: Deputy, the bandit's are escaping the OTHER way.
review:
I missed this set at first, and after it was dis-continued, my mother called and asked the catalog service if there were any more of this set. One year later, TLC re-releases it! This set is a great add on to a Western town. The left side of the jail flies off when you insert a dynamite piece through a slot, which hits a spring lever, which pops up and bumps the wall. There is a safe, a 1x2 tile (same size as dynamite) that represents a wanted poster, offering a $500 reward for Flatfoot Thompson, who I believe is the bandit in red in this set, a realistic Western leaning chair, a horse, and desk thats top lifts off to reveal gold coins. Minifigs are a sheriff, deputy/cowboy, bandit in green, and a bandit in red, who both have very detailed facial expressions.

NOTE: I have the re-released version, not this. But they're exactly the same piecewise

author: A_Brickset_user
title: An adequate supplement to the Western theme
review:
It was a long time before I bought this set since it's not as good value as the Gold City Junction.  Why buy 1 section for your town when you can have 2 plus a coach?  

This set is a decent stand alone set and cheaper option, and complements the theme quite well.  Worth buying just so you can have the Sherrif's office!  Twice as many figures as a Harry Potter set of the same size and more versatile bricks.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: original
review: I got the original set(not re-release) it is pretty cool but the dynamite is a bit hard to extract from the hole that blows the jail wall,my brother fixed the problem by inserting a 1x4 flat yellow piece insted(ya I know the color doesn't mach the theme).The porch roof that folds up is not very usefull although the pieces are very well used by now.My question is how the deputy got on the roof before he ran the wrong way?

author: sudorum
title: No Country For Old Men
review: Another great western set; it saddens me that the western theme is no longer around. It's just an old relic of the past now. Anyway, the inside of the sheriff's office features a rocking chair, a card table with a stash of gold under it, and a safe in the other half of the room. The small jail cell to the side has another one of the exploding traps from the city junction set. However, this time, the wall of the prison shoots off.

author: Gus_263
title: Western Chase
review: This set, is my third, and is one of the best ever. A good option to build western scenes, like chases. The four minifigures are really expressive. The Sheriff's Lock-Up have also some utilities, like the sheriff's weapons, hat and the bandits have some dynamites, that can be used in a system to unbuild the wall, freeing the other bandit. The horse, is another essencial option to do western chase scenes. A Classic and essencial set.

author: OWF
title: Excellent
review:
In 2000 I bought this set, I was very happy because I always wanted to have Western sets.
4 Minifigs, 2 bandits and 2 lawmen it's enough to play them and the building it big enough to have some fun with.
I was very surprised when I discovered the Jail trick, just drop a dynamite and the wall is running out.
There are a lot of accessories, pistols, rifles, cards, money.
Still one of my favorites Lego sets.

author: BM_Construction
title: Aweseome set!
review:
Flatfoot Thomsen is about to turn himself in for the $500 reward, but - what's this? The set only comes with $400! Flatfoot still gets thrown into jail, but the Sheriff doesn't know he's packed some dynamite in with him!

I love the exploding wall effect on this set. It really got my imagination going on stuff I could do with my Legos. The large barrel can also be turned into a water tower with one of those round saucer/lid type pieces (sorry I don't have the part number memorized) and the railing and log bricks can be used as supports.

SECRET TIP: There's a secret storage space under the Sheriff's desk. Perfect for stashing money or guns!

author: lego_lover2
title: One of the best sets LEGO has ever made!
review: This set is sweet! The exploding wall, the cowboys, the bombs, the money every thing! I love the good detail in this set! This set alows hours of fun filled time in the good-old wild west! I wish LEGO remakes this set! If you ever find this set, BUY IT!

author: Crazybrick45
title: AWSOME set!
review:
This set has load of functions, so lots of playability. The slanted roof on the sherrif's office tilts up and down. The sheriff's table opens up to put gold or a pistol in, and his chair tilts back. Probably the best function is the blow-away cell wall.. 

Pros:
4 minifigs. 
Lots of accesories.
Cell wall blows off when you put the dynamite piece in.
Quick build.

Cons:
Only 1 horse(there should be atleast 2, because, well, 4 minfigs..)

author: Korik4
title: One of the most fun sets ever
review:
As the box's picture may describe, this is one of the more exciting sets from Lego. And for that reason, one of the best. Whilst not being the biggest set in the world, there's a lot you can do with it. 

  For starters, there's four interesting minifigs included in the set, two 'bad' guys and two 'good' guys. Also featured are a rather large array of items for a set this size, such as guns, money, playing cards, dynamite and others. There's also a horse, (just one?) and a large-sized barrel not found in many sets. 

  The best feature of this set is the exploding door, which worked very well as I recall. As previously mentioned, I had a lot of fun playing with this set as a kid, so I would heartily recommend this as a toy for children. 

  This set is easy to build too, so you won't have to wait long before you can get to grips with this. Inside the sheriff's office there is a desk with a safe, and desk. 

  This set is average if you're looking for a good build but for fun or collection, one of the best sets of the time. Bring back the western theme!

author: frycook49
title: Fantastic!
review: An old set, yes. A great set, yes. The parts included were awesome and could be used to make a lot of variations. There was only 4 mini figures, but they were pretty nicely designed. It was fun to lock up mini-figures(either from this set or others) in the cage, and then for both kids and kids at heart, it really it is quite a creative set, with a lot of playability.

author: gigdoat2
title: Ye Olde Wild West
review:
This is the one Western set I own. Western sets are valuable online, so I am lucky to have it. I'll first review the minifigures, then the set.

I lost the sheriff. But the picture above shows he has a star badge, the large mustache used in pirate sets, and a grey cowboy hat. A great cowboy minifig.

The second good cowboy, whom I refer to as the deputy, is a great minifig. He has a standard cowboy torso, a head with white hair printed on it, and a white cowboy hat. He has a horse, with a saddle equipped with guns.

There are two bad cowboys. The first one with the cowboy hat has rotten teeth, a mustache, and a bandana. The second one has a green gambler torso, a face with teeth sticking out, one tooth golden, a mustache similar to his partner's, but better groomed.

The set has two components: the sheriff office and a small jail. I'll split this in two.

The sherrif office has two windows, a roof that flaps open, and a door. Within, there is a desk with a cup, poker cards(a good piece), and a secret compartment inside the desk that the sheriff can keep things in he doesn't want others to find. Behind the desk there is a rocking chair. There is also a safe with coins in it. Outside, there is a wanted sign for the bad cowboy, a bush, and a barrel.

In the jail, there is a one brick high and one stud wide hole behind it, and when dynamite is inserted, a function shoots a wall off. There is a fire outside the one small opening to make sure the resident can't get out.

A great set for your collection. I use it as the jail in my town, despite it's old west style. If you can get your hands on it, get it! 5/5

author: brycejo
title: Great Set
review: The set has stuff to make a Wild West Town because of the jail and sheriff office. Just like Gold City Junction and Fort Legoredo. And the jail has a mode to knock out the window with dynamite. It says it on the box and intructions.

author: RCT3Dude96
title: An oldie, but a goodie!
review: This was one of my first Lego sets back in around 2003, and even now it's an overall success. Endless fun in this set, from gambling cards, and using dynamite to blast out of jail. It had some awesome minifigures, and for a 20$ set, I thought that four was just right. The build wasn't difficult, and some graphics included multiple angles to make sure you don't screw up! Overall, it's worth hours of playability and it's a great western set!

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO Western - Sheriff's Lock-Up Review
review:
This is a very cool LEGO Western set to have in your LEGO collection. It's an easy built and this set is very sturdy. You also get a few stickers for the two windows and for the big sign on the top of the building. I love the mechanism of the jail where the wall can explode if you slide a stick of dynamite through the hole. We also get a white horse, a plant, a big keg where you can hide a minifig and a reward sign. The office for the sheriff is very nice to build. The door does open and the ceiling is movable. In the inside you can see a desk with a card game and a mug and the desk can be opened as well if you want to see some gold in the inside. There's also a sviwel chair and we get 4 cool minifigs as well. I think it's a great set to have in your LEGO Western or in your LEGO City collection.

All in all this set is a great set and I would HIGHLY recommend you to get this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full gallery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de


Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion 1
Stopmotion 2
Stopmotion 3
Stopmotion 4
Review

author: whaleyland
title: LEGO as an AfterThought: Ain't No Space Rangers Here
review:
The Westerners theme was one of the boldest, most stereotypical themes LEGO had ever done. Yet it was and remains the only LEGO theme focused on the American Wild West. Why this is, no one is quite sure, but it is probably similar to the Pirates theme in that LEGO intends to reboot it at some point in the near future. With the success of the CUUSOO Western Town project recently, I'm fairly certain the theme will be revived.

That all being said, let's have a look at the Sheriff's Lock-Up, the first of six sets I'll be reviewing of the Westerners line.

Innovations: The Westerners theme introduced to the world the "log" brick, a normal-sized brick that when coupled with other similar bricks looked like log walls. The Sheriff's office was the only building in town created completely out of them next to Fort Legorado. There is much to like about the Lock-Up, from the sloped pseudo-false front porch and building to the crenelated jail cell. But none of these were innovations unique to this set. The only real innovation was a bit of mechanics in the jail cell that caused the wall to blow open. A spring-loaded Technic piece rigged to pop out when a 1x2 plate was inserted into a gap in the wall did the trick, and boy it was fun to do over and over again.

Lack of Inspiration: However much I love the Westerners theme, there are always places where it lacks a certain flare. First and most importantly, the buildings are all very small with open backs. That's to be expected, but it provides little room for play. The jail cell too is overly detailed, which is unusual. The crenelation on the roof is not stylistically appropriate to the time, more appropriate to a castle than a block house. It's understandable that LEGO didn't want to just make a simple grey brick beside the Sheriff's office, but that would have been more appropriate. And like all of the LEGO minifigures of the 1990s, these figures are basic at best with no back details, simple face designs on the good guys, and generic repetition of figures among the series as a whole.

What it Got Right: Where the Sheriff's Lock-Up went right is in the balance of Sheriff and Deputy with inmate and conspirator. It also made certain to include a horse, though two or three would have been better. The stickers on the windows and on the roof are excellent, while the printed TNT, wanted poster, and playing cards are always fun to have around. The little details of the sage grass and the barrel were always hallmarks of the Westerners line, adding that extra touch that made it great. Even the raised flooring of the Sheriff's office is appropriate to the time and looks good.

Possible Improvements: Were this set to be remodeled and re-released, I think the cell block should be in darker grays with a much more solid feel to it. No wood bricks on its roof. The office itself should be larger, with a few more deputies, and the cell block could also be moved inside to match the Wild West stereotype better. The horse could definitely use the Lord of the Rings updating, and the windows could be printed, but otherwise most of this set is pretty well-done.

Minifigure: Where the Westerners did the most good but also the most wrong was with its characters. First off we get the sheriff. His face is the same we have seen on Pirates since 1989 and it still is unimpressive. The hat was the new style cowboy hat in a unique color with a printed star in the center, so no complaints there. His shirt shows a proper gentlemen in a grey suit coat and bowtie accompanied with a pocket watch and sheriff's star. The pants, though, are plain black and for whatever reason, he is wearing black gloves. Overall, a good figure in need of improvement. The cowboy has sandy blonde hair which is cut off awkwardly and seems more appropriate to the City theme. His white hat is unique to him and he is wearing a leather jacket over a red undershirt. Plain blue pants complete an ensemble that today would require printed pants for certain. Is he a deputy or just a cowboy? We'll never know.

There are two bad guys with this set, and neither are the leader. Bandit #2, as BrickSet calls him, is a mean guy with broken gold teeth showing and a rare printed nose. He wears a brown cowboy hat, black bandana, and grey pants. His shirt is red and stretching in parts, with printed suspenders and a black gunbelt. Today, the belt would be on the hips, leg paintings would show guns, and he'd have some sort of back painting on his bead. Still, a pretty unique individual here. Bandit #3 has most of his teeth in tact, but one is gold. He wears a black top hat, black gloves, and dark gray pants. His shirt shows a green blazer over a card symbol-checkered button-up, with a string tie and pocketwatch chain. He seems like he likes to gamble...a lot!

How it Compares: Overall, this is an excellent set and its original pricing was perfect. It includes four figures, a horse, and a nice set to play on with a fun trigger mechanism and little treasures in the Sheriff's office. It remains incomparable to modern sets because no Westerners sets have since been remade, but the hope will be that the entire line will get a reboot soon. If you ever get a chance to buy this set, pick it up ASAP.

author: Harmonious_Building
title: Lock, stock, and two smoking barrels.
review:
The Western theme was an early foray into a historical theme divorced from the Castle and Pirates lines, and I gather is looked upon fondly by AFOLs who lived through the era (namely, the era when LEGO Western sets were released, not the actual era of the American westward expansion). I wasn't so fortunate as to be able to have many of the Western sets myself, but I did own this one and do look back on it rather fondly.

 

One thing that I thought was attractive about the Western theme as a whole is the strong focus on buildings, and this idea works pretty well as far as LEGO is concerned since the early pioneers did have to work with only basic designs when they were getting the first towns started across the continental United States. The familiar "Wild West" look, popularised by Hollywood for decades now, translates well into LEGO, and is this iconic simplicity that we get a taste of in Sheriff's Lock-Up.

 

This set looks big, but I'm actually surprised to see that it's only got 176 pieces in it. The presence of the sand-coloured baseplate artificially expands the size of this set, but the low piececount is bolstered a generous helping of four Minifigs. None of the Minifigs are unique to this set, though they're all cool in their own way. I particularly like the "Bandit 3", the green-shirted gambler dude who could stand in as Daniel Day-Lewis' character from There Will Be Blood. Curiously, the folks on the law enforcement side utilise faces from Pirates and Ice Planet, which makes them seem almost qualitatively different from their criminal counterparts. In truth, I've always found the Western head designs to be a kind of strange, experimental flirtation with a new aesthetic, and since we AFOLs despise change, I find them  to be a bit unsettling, but not repugnantly so.

 

The early genesis of the LEGO police state begins right here, with this scene of a sheriff's office and the adjacent jail. Neither of the builds is terribly complicated, but the charming set-up offers lots of great playability. The fancier of the two constructions would be the jail, which features an interesting spring-loaded gimmick in which one can slide a 2-by-1 "dynamite" tile on the back of the jail and cause the side door to get pushed out. It's a nice mechanism that works well, and the inclusion of two bandits (and the two challengers) is, again, great from a playability point of view.

 

The sheriff's office features a lot of nice open space, and the hinged roofs above the patio serve the dual purpose providing an illusion of slantedness and also allow for easier access to the patio for the fat-fingered. The inside of the office provides a few cool details, including a sheriff's desk and a safe with a printed cover. Conversely and sadly, the window details are stickers. These are easy enough to apply, but most offensive of all is the "sheriff" sticker that adorns the top of the office, which is a single sticker that goes across two connected bricks.

 

Sheriff's Lock Up stands perfectly well on its own as an outpost of order in a lawless country, or it can be easily combined with the famous Gold City Junction (6765) as an additional structure for a newly-founded pioneer town. It's somewhat expensive considering the piececount, but the size of the structure and the number of Minifigs do soften the blow, but it's emblematic enough of the Western theme as a whole that it's worth the price.
